Ilja Preuss wrote:
> >> The trick is to refactor it so that it moves to a different class
> >> where it *should* be public. And in my experience, that's very
> >> likely always possible, in a way that makes the design more
> >> flexible and the behaviour more reusable. 
> >> 
> >> Does that sound reasonable?
> > 
> > 1. Are you doing this /just/ so that you can test the method
> > by external invocation? If so then my answer is no. 2. Is the
> > method already tested through the public API of the class? If
> > yes then my answer is no. 3. Does the system (code plus
> > tests) clearly communicate everything that needs to be
> > communicated at this time? If it does then my answer is no.
> > 4. Is the flexibility and reusability that you refer to
> > needed now or is it speculative? If the latter then my answer
> > is no. 5. Was my answer no to the previous questions and
> > there are more stories needing to be implemented this iteration?
> > Then heck no! 
> 
> I'm not doing this "just" for one thing. In my experience moving a
> complex method to a place where it wants to be public both
> 
> - makes the code more expressive,
> - makes the code easier to test,
> - makes the code more flexible, and thereby
> - helps me to maintain a high velocity.
> 
> Also keep in mind that moving the method often is only a first step,
> an enabler for further simplifying refactorings.
> 

Hmm. Sounds like you have your "Designer" hat on. That wasn't what I
understood to be the context of the question. "How do I test a private
method" is a question someone wearing their "Tester" hat would ask.
Given that context, my mind hasn't changed. If the private method is
already tested through an existing public method then you don't need
to do anything. In fact, exposing the method and writing an explicit
test against it is duplication.

Does that mean I believe Extract Class and Move Method are never used.
Of course not! But I don't think they provide a solution, per se, to
"How do I test a private method" unless the context includes "This
wasn't developed TDD and I don't have any confidence in it."

Maybe I'm wrong about this, but I tend to view each of the
refactorings as a mini-pattern: a solution to a problem in a context.
Each refactoring describes a motivation which includes the context.
For example, the motivation for Extract Class as described in
/Refactoring/ is that the class has too many responsibilities and has
lost cohesion. I don't see anything there about using the refactoring
to expose private methods of the class for testing. Likewise, the
motivation for Move Method doesn't include not being able to test a
method because of access restrictions. 

Maybe Martin Fowler wasn't wearing his Tester hat at the time. Maybe
he was and wanted to write a book about how to produce better designs,
not about solving problems with unit tests. So, third maybe in a row,
maybe refactorings shouldn't be viewed as ways to solve problems with
your the test suite? Or, maybe it would be an interesting topic to
write an article on -- how to apply refactorings when your focus is
testing and not design.

Regards,
Jim
